Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Interactive effects of predation and ecosystem size on arthropod food webs in Hawaiian forests fragmented by lava flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the combined effects of top predators and ecosystem size on the coexistence of species in food webs. Using numerous forest fragments of varying size that have been naturally created by lava flows in Hawai'i, the researchers will test the hypothesis that, as top predators, non-native rats alter food webs consisting of native birds, insects and spiders, with greater effects in smaller forest fragments. The study will involve experimental removal of rats, experimental exclusion of birds, stable isotope analysis of arthropods, and remote sensing analysis of forest size, complexity and productivity, all across a 100-fold gradient of forest fragment size.

Many forests around the world have been fragmented by development and pastoral land use, and also invaded by rats and other non-native predators. This project will improve the scientific basis for making management decisions, especially with regard to how non-native species removal can be used to restore native forests and how the effect may depend on forest size. This project will also enable the researchers to train a number of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows through their participation in research. Students will be recruited through internship programs at Stanford University and the University of Hawai'i, Hilo, which has a successful record of training under-represented students in environmental sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this collaborative research project, the investigators used forest fragments of varying size naturally created by lava flows on the Island of Hawaii to investigate combined effects of non-native rats and the size of forest fragments on the abundance and behavior of native forest birds, insects, and spiders. By removing rats by a grid system of snap traps from some of the forest fragments and contrasting them to comparable forests where rats were not removed, the investigators found that the demographic, behavioral, and functional impacts on native birds could all be predicted from the size of forest fragments. Rat removal increased bird abundance in some small, but not large, fragments, while shifting bird foraging locations more toward the forest floor in larger fragments. The investigators also found that birds played a greater role in larger fragments in controlling canopy insect and spider abundances in the presence of rats. However, this pattern disappeared when rats were removed. These fragment size-dependent consequences of rat removal could be explained by a greater amount of tall forest canopy, which served as spatial refuge from rats in larger fragments. In addition, it was also found that the patterns of individual movement of native birds, the genetic composition of dominant trees, and the species composition of the fungi associated with roots of these trees were all affected by the size of forest fragments as well as how isolated the fragments were from other forested areas in the landscape.

Intellectual merit of the study is that it is the first systematic experimental field test, to the investigators’ knowledge, of interactive effects of introduced omnivorous predators and ecosystem size in a terrestrial system at a large, whole-landscape scale, providing new knowledge on how the effects of non-native species introduction (rats in this case) on native species may depend on the size of the invaded ecosystems and why. Findings from this study have immediate relevance for the conservation and restoration of upper elevation Hawaiian forests, most of which have been fragmented by pastoral land-use and development and impacted by introduction of rats and other non-native predators. The study improves the scientific basis for making effective management decisions, especially with regards to understanding how rat removal can be used to restore native dominated food webs. The investigators have disseminated their findings through scientific publications, newsletter articles, and frequent correspondence with land managers, with whom the investigators sustain close partnerships. Rodent invasion and forest fragmentation are major causes of native biodiversity loss not just in Hawaii, but across the globe. Yet their potential interactive effects are poorly understood and often overlooked. Results of this study show how the effects of rat removal from invaded native ecosystems may depend on forest fragment size, complexity, and productivity, which have both local and global relevance. In addition, this project has enabled training of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows through their participation and collaboration in research. The undergraduate students were recruited through summer internship programs at Stanford University and the University of Hawaii, Hilo, which has a successful record of training under-represented and Native Hawaiian students in environmental sciences. Finally, this collaborative research has contributed to enhancing partnerships between three universities and the USDA Forest Service Institute of Pacific Islands Forestry.
